articles.headline: Credit Unions Are Beckoning With Open Arms
articles.snippet: Yes, you have to be a member to enjoy the benefits of nonprofit credit unions. But it may be easier to join than you think.
articles.abstract: Yes, you have to be a member to enjoy the benefits of nonprofit credit unions. But it may be easier to join than you think.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone can join a credit union, but not everyone can join any credit union.

articles.headline: Japan’s Far Right Blocks Screenings of ‘The Cove’
articles.snippet: An Oscar-winning documentary depicting dolphin hunting angered fringe groups in Japan.
articles.abstract: An Oscar-winning documentary depicting dolphin hunting angered fringe groups in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan  “The Cove,” an Oscar-winning documentary about dolphin hunting in Japan, would seem to be a natural fit for movie theaters here, but so far the distributor has yet to find a single one that will screen the film.

articles.headline: Hoping Tourists Will Flock to Hogwarts (and Spend a Few Galleons)
articles.snippet: Thousands of people lined up Friday to be among the first to see the Wizarding World attraction, Universal Orlando’s $265 million bet on a boy wizard.
articles.abstract: Thousands of people lined up Friday to be among the first to see the Wizarding World attraction, Universal Orlando’s $265 million bet on a boy wizard.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla.  First Harry Potter helped rejuvenate book publishing. Then he powered a boom in family mega-movies. Can the boy wizard now use his global popularity to give a lift to central Florida’s $31 billion tourism business?
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Catharine Skipp

articles.headline: A Tricky Balance for Oil-State Politicians
articles.snippet: Big energy companies help fill the campaign coffers of both Republican and Democratic lawmakers.
articles.abstract: Big energy companies help fill the campaign coffers of both Republican and Democratic lawmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The outburst by Representative Joe L. Barton of Texas in support of BP underscored the potential peril for lawmakers forced to respond to crises involving industries vital to their regions, and whose bountiful donations finance their political campaigns.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: U.S. Cracks Down on Farmers Who Hire Children
articles.snippet: The government is hiring investigators and raising fines on farmers who hire children and underpay workers.
articles.abstract: The government is hiring investigators and raising fines on farmers who hire children and underpay workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITE LAKE, N.C.  The Obama administration has opened a broad campaign of enforcement against farmers who employ children and underpay workers, hiring hundreds of investigators and raising fines for labor and wage violators.

articles.headline: Fuel Maker for Reactors Has China as Investor
articles.snippet: A company partly owned by China quietly bought a stake in America’s only provider of enriched fuel uranium.
articles.abstract: A company partly owned by China quietly bought a stake in America’s only provider of enriched fuel uranium.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A company here that is partly owned by the Chinese government has quietly purchased a 5.1 percent stake in the only American-owned provider of enriched uranium for use in civilian nuclear reactors.

articles.headline: BP Ignored the Omens of Disaster
articles.snippet: In the last five years, BP had two accidents that should have raised its focus on safety, and that makes the gulf disaster even more unforgivable.
articles.abstract: In the last five years, BP had two accidents that should have raised its focus on safety, and that makes the gulf disaster even more unforgivable.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We have to get the priorities right,” the chief executive of BP said. “And Job 1 is to get to these things that have happened, get them fixed and get them sorted out. We don’t just sort them out on the surface, we get them fixed deeply.”

articles.headline: Peddling Relief, Firms Put Debtors in Deeper Hole
articles.snippet: The recession has delivered an abundance of debt-saturated customers to settlement companies that take high fees regardless of whether debt is cut.
articles.abstract: The recession has delivered an abundance of debt-saturated customers to settlement companies that take high fees regardless of whether debt is cut.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla.  For the companies that promise relief to Americans confronting swelling credit card balances, these are days of lucrative opportunity.

articles.headline: Plus-Size Revelation: Bigger Women Have Cash, Too
articles.snippet: With nearly two-thirds of American women now overweight or obese, the fashion industry sees an opportunity to reinvigorate the market.
articles.abstract: With nearly two-thirds of American women now overweight or obese, the fashion industry sees an opportunity to reinvigorate the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corseted into a size 18 white denim dress, wearing heels that made her about 6-foot-2, Gwen DeVoe, a former model and fashion-show producer, stepped onto a runway in Manhattan this week and made a pitch to retailers for the plus-size woman.

articles.headline: Net Benefits of Biomass Power Under Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Doubts about biomass power threaten its viability as a renewable energy source as the nation seeks to diversify its energy portfolio.
articles.abstract: Doubts about biomass power threaten its viability as a renewable energy source as the nation seeks to diversify its energy portfolio.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENFIELD, Mass.  Matthew Wolfe, an energy developer with plans to turn tree branches and other woody debris into electric power, sees himself as a positive force in the effort to wean his state off of planet-warming fossil fuels.

articles.headline: China Signals a Gradual Rise in Value of Its Currency
articles.snippet: The move could deflect growing international criticism of the country’s fiscal policies.
articles.abstract: The move could deflect growing international criticism of the country’s fiscal policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  China announced on Saturday evening that it would allow greater flexibility in the value of its currency, a move that could deflect growing international criticism of its economic policies and defuse one of the greatest sources of tension between Beijing and Washington.

articles.headline: Baghdad Nights Glitter, Behind Shatterproof Glass
articles.snippet: Night life has returned in Baghdad with a restaurant that is part Beirut, part Dubai, part Miami circa “Scarface.”
articles.abstract: Night life has returned in Baghdad with a restaurant that is part Beirut, part Dubai, part Miami circa “Scarface.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  However loudly you protest, you still have to check your gun at the restaurant’s door. (Customers take valet tickets in return.) Guards in tight jeans and tighter shirts patrol the entrance, toting that ubiquitous paraphernalia of authority here: a walkie-talkie. Even cavalier guests cast leery glances down the road for a car that could be rigged with a bomb.

articles.headline: In Budget Crisis, States Take Aim at Pension Costs
articles.snippet: Many states, acknowledging that they have promised pensions they cannot afford, are reining in benefits — but only for future hires.
articles.abstract: Many states, acknowledging that they have promised pensions they cannot afford, are reining in benefits — but only for future hires.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many states are acknowledging this year that they have promised pensions they cannot afford and are cutting once-sacrosanct benefits, to appease taxpayers and attack budget deficits.

articles.headline: The Town That Loved Its Bank
articles.snippet: Residents in a Chicago suburb want the new owners of a bank, known for its community involvement, to act more like their predecessor.
articles.abstract: Residents in a Chicago suburb want the new owners of a bank, known for its community involvement, to act more like their predecessor.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAYWOOD, Ill.

articles.headline: Surgeon vs. Knee Maker: Who’s Rejecting Whom?
articles.snippet: A dispute offers a rare look at a clash between a top-shelf consultant and his corporate patron over patient safety.
articles.abstract: A dispute offers a rare look at a clash between a top-shelf consultant and his corporate patron over patient safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO

articles.headline: The Inflatable Loan Pool
articles.snippet: Amid the legal battles between investors who lost money in mortgage securities and the investment banks that sold the stuff, the investment banks appear to be winning many of the early skirmishes.
articles.abstract: Amid the legal battles between investors who lost money in mortgage securities and the investment banks that sold the stuff, the investment banks appear to be winning many of the early skirmishes.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMID the legal battles between investors who lost money in mortgage securities and the investment banks that sold the stuff, one thing seems clear: the investment banks appear to be winning a good many of the early skirmishes.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Stalwart Says Come, the Gulf’s Fine
articles.snippet: Gov. Haley Barbour’s performance could help shift his image from that of an insider party boss to an out-front crisis manager — and possible presidential candidate.
articles.abstract: Gov. Haley Barbour’s performance could help shift his image from that of an insider party boss to an out-front crisis manager — and possible presidential candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: GULFPORT, Miss.  “Get a picture of that beach!” Gov. Haley Barbour ordered a group of television photographers standing along an oil-less stretch of sand Monday.

articles.headline: Cost of Seizing Fannie and Freddie Surges for Taxpayers
articles.snippet: Now two of the country’s biggest landlords, the mortgage finance companies may wind up costing more than the banking industry rescue.
articles.abstract: Now two of the country’s biggest landlords, the mortgage finance companies may wind up costing more than the banking industry rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASA GRANDE, Ariz.  Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac took over a foreclosed home roughly every 90 seconds during the first three months of the year. They owned 163,828 houses at the end of March, a virtual city with more houses than Seattle. The mortgage finance companies, created by Congress to help Americans buy homes, have become two of the nation’s largest landlords.

articles.headline: Rise in Value of Currency to Be Slow, China Insists
articles.snippet: The central bank sought to reassure the Chinese people that a move toward a more flexible currency would not result in a sharp change.
articles.abstract: The central bank sought to reassure the Chinese people that a move toward a more flexible currency would not result in a sharp change.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A day after announcing that it would allow a more flexible currency, China said on Sunday that any appreciation in its value would be gradual, and it set the renminbi’s value in early trading on Monday at the same level as it traded on Friday.

articles.headline: Phone Software Takes the Taps Out of Typing
articles.snippet: Swype allows users to glide a finger across the virtual keyboard to spell words, rather than tapping out letters.
articles.abstract: Swype allows users to glide a finger across the virtual keyboard to spell words, rather than tapping out letters.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Back in the 1990s, typing out “hello” on most cellphones required an exhausting 13 taps on the number keys, like so: 44-33-555-555-666.

articles.headline: Israeli Easing of Blockade of Gaza Draws Praise of U.S.
articles.snippet: While Israel’s announcement did not signal an end to the naval blockade of Gaza, it earned some unusual praise from the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: While Israel’s announcement did not signal an end to the naval blockade of Gaza, it earned some unusual praise from the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Bowing to worldwide pressure and condemnation, Israel on Sunday formally announced an eased blockade of Gaza that could significantly expand the flow of goods overland into the impoverished coastal Palestinian enclave, isolated by the Israelis for three years.

articles.headline: Larry King’s Endgame at CNN
articles.snippet: Even as Mr. King celebrates 25 years in the same slot on the same network, CNN appears to have no clear successor.
articles.abstract: Even as Mr. King celebrates 25 years in the same slot on the same network, CNN appears to have no clear successor.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the beginning of June, CNN’s Larry King celebrated 25 years in the same slot on the same network  a remarkable achievement in a come-and-go business  and was joined over a week by Bill Gates, LeBron James and the leader of the free world to mark the occasion. Not bad for a former color commentator of the Shreveport Steamer of the World Football League.

articles.headline: As China Aids Labor, Unrest Is Still Rising
articles.snippet: Laws enacted in 2008 to protect workers have raised worker consciousness and may be contributing to a rise in labor disputes.
articles.abstract: Laws enacted in 2008 to protect workers have raised worker consciousness and may be contributing to a rise in labor disputes.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  On a hot morning in late May, while some 2,000 workers at a Honda parts factory were striking in China’s south, 100 irate employees at a hotel in the heart of the capital staged their own protest.

articles.headline: Bank Lobbyists Make a Run at Reform Measures
articles.snippet: Maneuvering continues over risky wagers on the market and selling off hedge funds and private equity units.
articles.abstract: Maneuvering continues over risky wagers on the market and selling off hedge funds and private equity units.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Congress rushes this week to complete the most far-reaching financial reform plan in decades, the banking industry is mounting an 11th-hour end run.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: In NBC-Comcast Deal, Quiet Concerns
articles.snippet: As public comments on Comcast’s proposed merger close, local television broadcasters have been noticeably silent about the plans of the cable provider, known as a bruising competitor.
articles.abstract: As public comments on Comcast’s proposed merger close, local television broadcasters have been noticeably silent about the plans of the cable provider, known as a bruising competitor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Comcast, the nation’s biggest cable provider, has long played hardball with competitors and content providers. Now that it is seeking control of NBC Universal in a $30 billion transaction, those competitors are piping up, expressing fears that Comcast will use its consolidated power to favor its own content and squeeze out rivals.

articles.headline: Looking to Expand, a Hollywood Agency Seeks a Financial Boost
articles.snippet: Bryan Lourd and the Creative Artists Agency are hoping to form a financial alliance that may give the agency backing for new ventures.
articles.abstract: Bryan Lourd and the Creative Artists Agency are hoping to form a financial alliance that may give the agency backing for new ventures.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When talks over the Walt Disney Company’s attempted sale of Miramax Films bogged down last month, Bryan Lourd, a managing partner in the powerful Creative Artists Agency, jumped in.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Regulators Failed to Address Risks in Oil Rig Fail-Safe Device
articles.snippet: The federal agency charged with regulating offshore drilling repeatedly declined to act on advice on how it could minimize the risk of a failure of the device, an examination found.
articles.abstract: The federal agency charged with regulating offshore drilling repeatedly declined to act on advice on how it could minimize the risk of a failure of the device, an examination found.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by  David Barstow,  Laura Dodd,  James Glanz,  Stephanie Saul and  Ian Urbina.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Cites Asset Firm in a Fraud
articles.snippet: The case against ICP Asset Management involves a new type of target for regulators in their pursuit of wrongdoing in the mortgage market.
articles.abstract: The case against ICP Asset Management involves a new type of target for regulators in their pursuit of wrongdoing in the mortgage market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beginning a new stage in the government’s investigations of the mortgage industry, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday accused a New York firm that managed complex mortgage securities of defrauding investors and misleading the American International Group, the government-controlled company that insured some of the firm’s deals.

articles.headline: Court Affirms Ban on Aiding Groups Tied to Terror
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court rejected a First Amendment challenge to a federal law that bars giving “material support” to terrorist organizations.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court rejected a First Amendment challenge to a federal law that bars giving “material support” to terrorist organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In a case pitting free speech against national security, the Supreme Court on Monday upheld a federal law that makes it a crime to provide “material support” to foreign terrorist organizations, even if the help takes the form of training for peacefully resolving conflicts.
